text: today I'm excited to share with you a
formula really for rich creamy vegetable
soups it's really only two things you
need a vegetable of your choice and you
also need a base today I'm going to show
a veloute which is one of the mother
sauces and it's really simple to make
it's only four ingredients so let's get
started into a small pot I have five
tablespoons of unsalted butter and I'm
going to basically be making a roux now
the one difference here is that I'm
going to sweat some onions in with the
butter before I add my flour so I have
one small onion here that's diced up now
you don't need to worry about dicing it
super super fine because we're going to
blend the soup together in the end and
this will take just a few minutes for
the onions to soften and sweat now
classically cream soups were made with a
totally different base they were made
with a bechamel and if you guys remember
a bechamel is another mother sauce that
is made out of milk that is thickened
with a roux but oftentimes when you
create a cream soup based on that base
the vibrancy of color isn't as great and
it's also a little bit heavier having
this thickened stock this veloute is
lighter silkier and it also adds a
greater dimension of flavor because you
have chicken stock or a flavored stock
included so now the onions have become
translucent they're losing some other
moisture and I'm going to add the flour
again this is the other component to the
roux which is going to thicken this
whole soup so I have a quarter cup plus
one tablespoon of flour and I'm going to
whisk this in to my butter and onion
mixture and you want to cook the flour a
little bit you want to get rid of that
raw flour taste the longer you cook the
flour the more nutty it will get so just
a minute is fine here and now I'm going
to slowly add my chicken stock so I have
four cups of chicken stock here add a
little bit of you
or stock into your mixture here and you
want to whisk vigorously to make sure
that you avoid the clump so whisking
vigorously and adding in stages here
will help to avoid having a clumpy
mixture so this looks pretty good and
the rest of the chicken stock here now
you want to bring this up to a boil and
then reduce it down to a simmer and
simmer this for about ten minutes until
it gets nice and thick again whenever
you're working with flour or if it's
cornstarch any starch has to be brought
up to a boil in order for it to reach
its thickening potential so as this
cooks in simmers I'm going to work on
the vegetable portion so there are two
components remember the base and the
vegetables so you could really do
anything here the possibilities are
endless today I'm going to be using
spinach but I have some other examples
of vegetables that you could use here
broccoli mushrooms and cauliflower you
could do asparagus really anything that
you love in a soup you could put into
this what you need is about one and
three-quarter pounds to two pounds of
the raw vegetable and then you have to
cook it you have to get rid of some of
that liquid today with the spinach I'm
going to blanch this in some boiling
salted water here just for a minute or
two and I would do the same thing with
asparagus I would do the same thing with
broccoli with the mushrooms to really
develop the flavor I would suggest
sauteing them but the base amount that
you'll need is about one and
three-quarter pounds to two pounds of
the vegetable so you really only want to
blanch this miniature for about a minute
because you want to maintain that bright
green color and I'm going to plunge this
immediately into some ice water to stop
the cooking process to maintain that
wonderful color so now once the spinach
has cooled down enough what you're going
to do is you're going to squeeze out any
excess moisture you want to make sure
that you remove the excess moisture so
that your soup isn't too light or too
runny so the veloute is nice and
thick now as you can see this does not
have the texture of a bechamel it's not
very thick and pasty it's lighter in
silkier and now I'm going to blend our
spinach and our veloce together so again
you do this with any vegetable you like
if you like corn you could blanch some
corn or sautee some corn and add that
here but any vegetable really and now
ladle in half of this right over the
spinach and then put the top on your
blender and whenever you're blending
something that's hot you want to remove
the little middle guy the little middle
insert here and place a towel over the
top because what you're doing is you're
blending this up and it's hot and
there's steam in there so if this
mixture is closed off and contained what
might happen is the top might actually
pop up and create more of an explosion
so use a towel leave it slightly ajar
and start on a lower speed and then you
want to bring it up to a higher speed
okay you can see how beautiful the color
is here and again it really helps to use
a veloute as opposed to a bechamel you
will get a beautiful emerald green color
if you're making broccoli if you're
making spinach like I am now I'm going
to strain this mixture through a sieve
just in case there are any little pieces
of spinach left into a clean pot and I'm
just going to finish up with my second
batch here so the second batch is done
here again right through a sieve and so
now for the final touch here you need to
season the soup up a little bit so I'm
going to add some salt now if you wanted
some pepper here you could certainly do
that I'm a big fan of black pepper but
if you didn't want to see little flecks
of black pepper in your soup you could
certainly use white pepper that's very
classic it's very French and also to
gild the lily add a half a cup of heavy
cream you can turn your burner on a very
low heat to bring this up to a nice hot
temperature but you don't really want to
bring this mixture up to a boil because
you might end up curdling the cream
slightly and also your vibrant green
color is also going to start to get a
little bit darker more like an olivey
grain if you do heat this up to high so
ladle this delicious soup right into
your serving bowl if you want to get
serious you should warm your serving
bowl before serving this because then it
will stay warmer longer and you could
top this off with a little bit of extra
heavy cream or as I like to do some
croutons there you go guys now if you
have any kitchen conundrums cooking
conundrums baking conundrums whatever
write in the comment section below we'd
love to hear from you guys and as always
the wintertime enjoy some warm soup
you
